About 8 years ago I was backpacking in Australia. I ended up in an extremely remote location in the Daintree Rainforest called Cape Tribulation.   This place was so remote that the place I was working at was running off of their own generator as there was no electricity grid installed on the island. Everywhere you would look there were signs saying to stay out of the salt-water crocodile infested waters- you couldnâ€™t miss them there were so many.   One evening, a bunch of us went to the beach to have a fire, play some music and watch a meteor shower. It was absolutely beautiful. The next day a bunch of crocodile hunters (rangers) showed up at our remote resort and we discovered that approximately 10 minutes walk down the road two ladies went night swimming in these waters for their adrenaline fix. One lady felt something brush past her leg, and the next minute her friend was pulled underwater and never seen again.   The crocodile was found with her remains still inside the belly. It was killed because of their selfish decision to go swimming at 11pm in the most crocodile infested waters in Australia.   For anyone wondering, they need to find the crocodile that killed the human because they get a taste for them and actively hunt humans afterwards!  Edit: the ladyâ€™s name was â€˜Cindy Waldronâ€™

My mum told her to get her kids out immediately, the woman was a bit dismissive until my mother pointed to the sign warning about crocs in the water that she had completely ignored. Reminds me of the time I was in Garden of the God's hiking one of the beautiful trails...came upon a Park Ranger, she was holding folks back while a beautiful rattlesnake was crossing the trail (pretty sure it was a Mojave Green although they aren't supposed to be up there). A fellow came striding up behind me, pushing his way through those of us who were waiting for the snake to make its way across. I stepped in front of him to stop him as he clearly wasn't paying attention to anything other than shouldering past us and straight into the rattler. He was clearly upset with me, but I calmly explained that the Ranger (one the downhill side, we were uphill, of the snake) wanted us to wait until the snake was across & into the rocks. The man (in sandals) said "I'm from Arizona, we aren't afraid of snakes" and pushed past me (normally I wouldn't allow a man to do that, but I figured the snake could teach him a better lesson...so I let him go). Idiots will be idiots regardless of how much good advice we try to impart.

We have similar issues up here on the Washington State Coast. We lose tourists and children every year to the riptide. (To anyone reading this: if you're ever swimming toward shore but getting farther away, the ocean is pulling you out. Just rest and float for a while until the land stops shrinking. Then swim parallel to the coast until you feel the water change. That's when it's safe to swim to shore, and the current will take you there. Think of riptides like a comb, the teeth pull you out to sea while the gaps take you back to shore.)  Edited because autocorrect really autofailed this time smh.

Crocs in Florida are not aggressive ğŸ˜‚   â€œNo, crocodiles in Florida are not generally aggressive towards humans:  Temperament American crocodiles are shy and reclusive, and conflicts with humans are rare.  Behavior When surprised, crocodiles will quickly and noisily enter the water. This behavior indicates that they are frightened, but it shouldn't be mistaken for aggression.  History There have been few documented attacks on humans by crocodiles in Florida. In 2014, a crocodile bit a man and woman in a canal in Coral Gables, but it released them and moved away. â€œ

He may have even been caught in the current, but he kept yelling that he was fine. It was really sad and even took the lifeguards half an hour to recover his body because of the dangerous lava rock bluffs. A helicopter was hovering above the whole rescue time, and air lifted him away when they finally got him. A 23 year old man's life lost because of confidence. Just listen to the locals, and don't be afraid to show humility if something is going wrong.  This happened at Kahena Beach on the Big Island in April of 2019, on a Sunday. The guy's name was Tyler. I loved the "Be crocwise" and "You are in croc country" signs when I was in Northern Territory and always respected them. Nevertheless I took a quick dip directly at Cahills crossing because I had cycled there from Darwin and seriously needed to cool down. Of course it was low tide and there had formed a small pool beside the causeway that was somehow sheltered by rocks. An hour later the place was flooded and the air filled with snapping and crushing sounds from hundreds of crocs feasting on barramundis. Amazing memories of Down Under!

I've seen big Saltie up in small fresh water creek's all through fnq mainly small Crocs but a few years it won't be small somehow getting up the creeks maybe when young and during a flood. I'm guessing but having said this salt water crocs can get into fresh water creek and remaining for years undetectable so to make my point finally after a big rant any salt water river like this at the river mouth even small amounts of salt is a no no to go into in FNQ.
